au_1334902: $ sudo mount {LV_PATH} /path/to/mount/point/
$ sudo mount /dev/LVM_Group_Name/home /mnt/My_Lovely_Partition_Name/home
$ sudo mount /dev/LVM_Group_Name/root /mnt/My_Lovely_Partition_Name/root

su_1360276: sudo umount /mnt/d
sudo mount -t drvfs D: /mnt/d

Explanations about Options.-t:
The argument following the -t is used to indicate the filesystem type. The
 filesystem types which are currently supported depend on the running kernel. See
 /proc/filesystems and /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/kernel/fs for a complete list of the
 filesystems. The most common are ext2, ext3, ext4, xfs, btrfs, vfat, sysfs, proc,
 nfs and cifs.

Top-3 Similar Questions: au_308226: Accessing Window Files in Linux

Explanations about Options.-l:
List the partition tables for the specified devices and then exit. If no devices
 are given, those mentioned in /proc/partitions (if that file exists) are used.

Explanations about Options.-s:
Display swap usage summary by device. Equivalent to "cat /proc/swaps". This
 output format is DEPRECATED in favour of --show that provides better control on
 output data.
